Supersedes IRM 13.2.4, Systemic Advocacy, Information Gathering Projects, dated 11-04-2020. The following IRM Procedural Update (IPU) 21U0689, issued May 4, 2021 have been incorporated into this IRM.
Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS), primarily employees within Systemic Advocacy (SA).
Table of Contents
Gathering Projects (IGP)

) This IRM section describes the types of Information Gathering Projects used by Systemic Advocacy (SA) and the process for working each type of project. The IGPs are used to track emerging issues, conduct further to determine whether an issue is systemic, or to propose alternative to an IRS Internal Management Document (IMD) using an Out of Clearance Process (OCP) form. (
) Audience: TAS, primarily employees within SA. (
) Policy Owner: National Taxpayer Advocate (NTA), TAS (
) Program Owner: Executive Director Systemic Advocacy (EDSA) (

) Contact Information Employees should contact the Product Content Owner provided on the Product Catalog Information page for this IRM. To changes or make any other suggestions related to this IRM section, see
, Providing Feedback About an IRM Section - Outside of Clearance. (

) Throughout the Taxpayer Advocacy Service (TAS), employees play a vital in identifying, analyzing, and resolving broad-based taxpayer problems. taxpayer problems are brought to TAS’s attention through several sources including offices within TAS, Internal Revenue Service (IRS) employees, taxpayers, practitioners, and other external stakeholders. (

) TAS SA plays a vital role in identifying, analyzing, and resolving taxpayer problems. IGPs arise from several sources, including Case (CA) offices within TAS, IRS employees in other functions, and external holders. (

) SA starts with Systemic Advocacy Management System (SAMS) and then applies the tools of project management when working the IGPs developed from these submissions, informing stakeholders of the progress an IGP and the ﬁnal results. These items are the essence of SA analysis initiatives. (
) Internal Revenue Code (IRC) §

(c) established the Office of the Advocate to assist taxpayers with resolving problems with the IRS, identify areas in which taxpayers have problems dealing with the IRS, propose changes in the administrative practices of IRS, and identify potential changes to mitigate problems. (

) The EDSA reports directly to the NTA. The EDSA has oversight for systemic advocacy and the NTA’s Annual Reports to Congress. Two divisions, Proactive Advocacy and Technical Advocacy, report to the EDSA. The Deputy Executive Director Systemic Advocacy, Proactive Advocacy (DEDSA-PA) and the Deputy Executive Director Systemic Advocacy, Advocacy (DEDSA-TA), are responsible for identifying and raising of systemic issues impacting taxpayers. The DEDSA-PA is responsible for production of the NTA ARC, the receipt and control of advocacy issues, and the internal management document process. The DEDSA-TA is responsible the advocacy initiative tracking system, assignment of advocacy projects, advocacy proposals, and a database which captures advocacy projects, proposals, and initiatives. TAS SA receives administrative and legislative proposals from a multitude of sources, including internal and external Internal Revenue Manual
Gathering Projects (IGP) 13.2.4

areas in which taxpayers have problems dealing with the IRS, propose changes in the administrative practices of IRS, and identify potential legislative changes to mitigate problems. The EDSA reports directly to the NTA. The EDSA has oversight responsibility for systemic advocacy and the NTA’s Annual Reports to Congress. Two divisions, Proactive Advocacy and Technical Advocacy, report to the EDSA. The Deputy Executive Director Systemic Advocacy, Proactive Advocacy (DEDSA
PA) and the Deputy Executive Director Systemic Advocacy, Technical Advocacy (DEDSA
TA), are responsible for identifying and raising awareness of systemic issues impacting taxpayers. The DEDSA
PA is responsible for the production of the NTA ARC, the receipt and control of advocacy issues, and the internal management document process. The DEDSA

TA is responsible for the advocacy initiative tracking system, assignment of advocacy projects, advocacy proposals, and a database which captures advocacy projects, proposals, and initiatives. TAS SA receives administrative and legislative proposals from a multitude of sources, including internal and external sources.
Systemic (

) Advocacy analysts assigned to SA work with the IRS Business Operating Divisions/Functional Units (BOD/FU) to analyze and understand the root causes of problems and support joint advocacy efforts. The ultimate goals the advocacy analysts are to ensure the taxpayer’s fundamental rights are protected, IRS decisions consider taxpayer interest and the reduction of taxpayer burden, improve customer service, and address the inequitable treatment of taxpayers. (

) SA has established a series of organizational measurements to address program effectiveness through direct oversight of three Technical Advocacy and Directors by conducting reviews monthly as structured in the TAS Program Review Letter. (

) Program Goals - The processes and procedures provided in this IRM are: • To evaluate whether a submission is a systemic issue; Controls • To research and gather information to determine the potential taxpayers and on processes and procedures; • To follow the Taxpayer Bill of Rights (TBOR) which clearly outlines fundamental rights of every taxpayer; and • To evaluate proposed procedural changes initiated by the IRS BOD/ FUs. (
) Program Reports –SA uses Business Objects Enterprise (BOE) for the reporting of program objectives. (

) Annual Review –The three Directors of Technical Advocacy (Exam, and Processing) are responsible for reviewing the information in this IRM annually to ensure accuracy and promote consistent tax administration. Director of Advocacy Efforts has the responsibility for oversight of the program reviews. (
) The use of abbreviations and acronyms are located in IRM
, SA Overview. See Exhibit
, Terms and Acronyms, for commonly used terms and abbreviations. (
) Additional SA program information and resources are available as provided below: Resources • TAS, SAMShttps://www.irs.gov/advocate/systemic-advocacy- management-system-sams • IRM
, IMD/SPOC Reviews • IRM

(a) prohibits unauthorized disclosure of tax returns and return mation. Taxpayer (
) TAS employees must be aware of information that must be protected, how protect it, and how to dispose of or destroy the information when it is no required. (
) Taxpayers can expect that TAS will keep their information conﬁdential and share information only as necessary and only as authorized by law. See

(09-30-2020) Types of Information Gathering Projects (IGPs)

Types of IGPs Purpose Monitor The purpose of a Monitor IGP is to track SAMS issues or develop- ments related to an emerging issue. For example, SA may wish to collect information related to the passage of new legislation or a new administrative procedure. Generally, Monitor IGPs have a one-year lifespan or less. A deter- mination is made whether to keep the IGP open for further monitor- ing, to close without further action, or to recommend an advocacy vehicle. Research The purpose of a Research IGP is to conduct additional research to determine if an issue is a systemic problem. It is typically created if the SAMS issue review process was unable to determine whether a systemic problem exists. The goal is to close the IGP and move the issue to the proper advocacy vehicle within 90 days or less.

Purpose The purpose of a Monitor IGP is to track SAMS issues or develop- ments related to an emerging issue. For example, SA may wish to collect information related to the passage of new legislation or a new administrative procedure. Generally, Monitor IGPs have a one-year lifespan or less. A deter- mination is made whether to keep the IGP open for further monitor- ing, to close without further action, or to recommend an advocacy vehicle. The purpose of a Research IGP is to conduct additional research to determine if an issue is a systemic problem. It is typically created if the SAMS issue review process was unable to determine whether a systemic problem exists. The goal is to close the IGP and move the issue to the proper advocacy vehicle within
days or less.

The purpose of a Research IGP is to conduct additional research to determine if an issue is a systemic problem. It is typically created if the SAMS issue review process was unable to determine whether a systemic problem exists. The goal is to close the IGP and move the issue to the proper advocacy vehicle within
days or less.

The purpose of an IMD/SPOC IGP is to recommend language for IMDs. Typically, this involves reviewing changes proposed by a SAMS submitter or drafting language. Generally, the language change will be proposed to the IRS through an Out of Clearance Process (OCP) request. The goal is to close the IGP in
calendar days or less.
The SIRE Program Manager assigns the IGP to the DEDSA

TA, and Technical Advocacy Director Project Manager; An email is sent from SIRE to conﬁrm the assignment; and The Technical Advocacy Director assigns the IGP to a team lead (On ″ SAMS, the Technical Advocacy Director is displayed as the Project ″ Manager .)

Affordable Care Act law provisions require new and changed IRS processes and new reporting requirements for taxpayers. SA creates a Monitor IGP so that SAMS issues related to the changes can be associ- ated, and the project team lead can add notes about IRS actions or TAS concerns.

) A Monitor IGP differs from other systemic vehicles in that the urgency and sub- sequent actions are dependent upon the issue. The team lead should focus attention on the appropriate IGP, based on the nature of the issue and recommend next actions. (
) In addition to reviewing related SAMS issues, the team lead should monitor
Gathering Projects (IGP) 13.2.4
The team lead should document examples and other relevant information using the “Notes” tab and/or uploading to the “Files” tab on SAMS.

While monitoring Affordable Care Act implementation, the team lead learns that taxpayers making withdrawals from their retirement accounts are not being informed that this will affect their eligibility for the Premium Tax Credit. The team lead recommends creating an Advocacy Project to pursue improvements in guidance from the IRS and the Marketplace.
Document a status update at the end of each calendar quarter in the “Notes” tab on SAMS using the note type Status Update. Use the following format for status updates:
Issue: This is a brief re-stated description of the issue, including the real or potential impact on taxpayers. This description may be constant from update to update.
Actions to Date: Brieﬂy describe important actions to date. Include research, communications with the IRS or other stakeholders, and other
Note: A quarterly status update is required regardless of assignment date.
) Common outcomes for a Monitor IGP include: a. Creation of an advocacy vehicle(s) b. Closing the IGP (

) Typically, the Monitor IGP has a one-year life cycle. If the determination is continue beyond the year, discuss the reasons with the SAMS Project Manager. If the SAMS Project Manager agrees, the SAMS Project Manager will document approval in the “Notes” tab on SAMS. (

) After research is completed, the team lead updates SAMS with summary recommendations and notiﬁes the SAMS Project Manager, who then and documents approval in the “Notes” tab on SAMS. The SAMS Project Director (DEDSA-TA) completes the ﬁnal approval and closes the IGP on SAMS. (

) Create a Research IGP when SIRE is unable to determine whether the is systemic. The goals of a Research IGP are to: • Gather and analyze information; • Determine whether an issue is systemic; and • Recommend TAS’s next step. (

) The Research IGP is an extension of the issue review process, so it is tive to work the IGP with a sense of urgency and quickly identify the proper advocacy vehicle. The goal is to close the IGP and move the issue to the proper advocacy vehicle within
days or less.
) Review the information from the issue review process and summarize the purpose of the IGP on the “Notes” tab on SAMS. and (

) All actions and information affecting the outcome of the Research IGP be documented on the “Notes” tab on SAMS. Document actions taken on the day completed. Documentation should include facts and analysis used to the closing recommendation. (

) Documentation should include substantive actions taken to move the IGP ″ ″ forward and should not state, working on the IGP. Summarize emails and avoid cutting and pasting entire emails onto the “Notes” tab. Attach entire emails to ﬁles only if necessary, to support the outcome.

) Attach only the applicable portion of documents to the“Files” tab and avoid attaching entire IRMs or other large documents. (

) Do not include tax return information or Personally Identiﬁable Information on SAMS. PII is any information that, by itself or in combination with other formation, may be used to uniquely identify an individual. Examples of PII include name, address, telephone numbers, place of employment, etc. For more complete list of PII, see the Disclosure and Privacy Knowledge Base on the intranet. (
) For Research IGPs, the analyst is required to make initial contact with the submitter within

business days from the “Assignment Date” on SAMS. During the initial contact, advise the submitter of project assignment and conﬁrm a clear understanding of the issue. The initial contact provides an portunity to determine whether additional information is available or if have occurred. All contact will be documented on SAMS and will include stantive detail of what was discussed. The substance of the discussion be documented on the “Notes” tab as a “contact.” The initial contact can be telephone call or email. (
) The Advocacy team lead will contact the submitter before closing the IGP to discuss the results and recommendations. (
) The analyst is required to send an email of the closing recommendation to or her manager within
calendar days of IGP completion. The submitter

) Upon closing contact, thank the submitter for their participation in the program and encourage the submitter to contact SA if they identify other systemic issues. Document SAMS with a summary of the closing contact the submitter. (
) Review and analyze the information gathered during the issue review develop an action plan for advocacy resolution. (
) Conduct additional research to determine the underlying cause of the issue, making sure to document all research on the “Notes” tab on SAMS, using type, “Research”. (

) The most common results of a Research IGP are to create an Advocacy Project, Immediate Intervention, collaborative effort team, or a task force. (
) IGPs may be referred for consideration in the ARC as a legislative change Most Serious Problem. An IGP may also be referred to an existing team or task force already working the issue. (
) If the IGP was determined to not be systemic, it may be closed as “not validated as systemic.” (

) To close the case, take the following action: • Contact the submitter before closing the IGP to discuss the results recommendations, unless promoted to an advocacy project. team lead will contact the submitter.) • Within

calendar days, update the SAMS “Notes”tab when closing Research IGP and document a closing summary with the disposition. The Project Manager approves the disposition and refers the closure to the SAMS Project Director (DEDSA-TA), depending on the recommended disposition. ) Some issues raised in SAMS submissions may require changes to IRS guidance. If management determines SA should pursue a change, an IMD/ SPOC IGP is created. The goal of an IMD/SPOC IGP is the submission of an OCP IMD/SPOC recommendation through the IMD/SPOC Center. (

13.2.4.7.1.1 (10-19-2022) Submitter Contact
The analyst is required to send an email of the closing recommendation to Project Manager within 14 calendar days of IGP completion.

) Closing the IMD/SPOC IGP: a. Once the OCP template is sent to *TAS IMD/SPOC, wait for the edgement from IMD/SPOC with the assignment identiﬁcation number complete the Closing Summary on the “Notes” tab on SAMS and note the type as “Closing Summary”. IMD/SPOC is responsible for the OCP process. b. Upload OCP template to the “Files” tab on SAMS. c. The SAMS Technical Advocacy Director approves the disposition and refers the closure to the SAMS Project Director (DEDSA-TA) to close IGP on SAMS.
